refsynopsisdiv.title: Synopsis
refsynopsisdiv.synopsis:
#include <glib.h>
#define GLIB_MAJOR_VERSION #define GLIB_MINOR_VERSION #define GLIB_MICRO_VERSION
#define G_OS_WIN32 #define G_OS_BEOS #define G_OS_UNIX
#define GLIB_CHECK_VERSION (major,minor,micro)
#define G_DIR_SEPARATOR #define G_DIR_SEPARATOR_S #define G_SEARCHPATH_SEPARATOR #define G_SEARCHPATH_SEPARATOR_S
#define TRUE #define FALSE
#define NULL
#define MIN (a, b) #define MAX (a, b)
#define ABS (a) #define CLAMP (x, low, high)
#define G_STRUCT_MEMBER (member_type, struct_p, struct_offset) #define G_STRUCT_MEMBER_P (struct_p, struct_offset) #define G_STRUCT_OFFSET (struct_type, member)
#define G_MEM_ALIGN
#define G_CONST_RETURN

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: These macros provide a few commonly-used features.

refsect2.title: GLIB_MAJOR_VERSION
refsect2.para: The major version number of the GLib library.

refsect2.title: GLIB_MINOR_VERSION
refsect2.para: The minor version number of the GLib library.

refsect2.title: GLIB_MICRO_VERSION
refsect2.para: The micro version number of the GLib library.

refsect2.title: G_OS_WIN32
refsect2.para: This macro is defined only on Windows. So you can bracket Windows-specific code in "#ifdef G_OS_WIN32".

refsect2.title: G_OS_BEOS
refsect2.para: This macro is defined only on BeOS. So you can bracket BeOS-specific code in "#ifdef G_OS_BEOS".

refsect2.title: G_OS_UNIX
refsect2.para: This macro is defined only on UNIX. So you can bracket UNIX-specific code in "#ifdef G_OS_UNIX".

refsect2.title: GLIB_CHECK_VERSION()
G_DIR_SEPARATOR
refsect2.para: The directory separator character. This is '/' on UNIX machines and '\' under Windows.

refsect2.title: G_DIR_SEPARATOR_S
refsect2.para: The directory separator as a string. This is "/" on UNIX machines and "\" under Windows.

refsect2.title: G_SEARCHPATH_SEPARATOR
refsect2.para: The search path separator character. This is ':' on UNIX machines and ';' under Windows.

refsect2.title: G_SEARCHPATH_SEPARATOR_S
refsect2.para: The search path separator as a string. This is ":" on UNIX machines and ";" under Windows.

refsect2.title: TRUE
refsect2.para: Defines the TRUE value for the gboolean type.

refsect2.title: FALSE
refsect2.para: Defines the FALSE value for the gboolean type.

refsect2.title: NULL
refsect2.para: Defines the standard NULL pointer.

refsect2.title: MIN()
refsect2.para: Calculates the minimum of a and b.

listitem.simpara: the minimum of a and b.

refsect2.title: MAX()
refsect2.para: Calculates the maximum of a and b.

listitem.simpara: the maximum of a and b.

refsect2.title: ABS()
refsect2.para: Calculates the absolute value of a. The absolute value is simply the number with any negative sign taken away.

For example,
ABS(-10) is 10.
ABS(10) is also 10.

refsect2.title: CLAMP()
refsect2.para: Ensures that x is between the limits set by low and high.

For example,
CLAMP(5, 10, 15) is 10.
CLAMP(15, 5, 10) is 10.
CLAMP(20, 15, 25) is 20.

listitem.simpara: the value of x clamped to the range between low and high.

refsect2.title: G_STRUCT_MEMBER()
refsect2.para: Returns a member of a structure at a given offset, using the given type.

listitem.simpara: the type of the struct field.
the offset of the field from the start of the struct, in bytes.

refsect2.title: G_STRUCT_MEMBER_P()
refsect2.para: Returns an untyped pointer to a given offset of a struct.

listitem.simpara: the offset from the start of the struct, in bytes.
an untyped pointer to struct_p plus struct_offset bytes.

refsect2.title: G_STRUCT_OFFSET()
refsect2.para: Returns the offset, in bytes, of a member of a struct.

listitem.simpara: a field in the structure, e.g. window.
the offset of member from the start of struct_type.

refsect2.title: G_MEM_ALIGN
refsect2.para: Indicates the number of bytes to which memory will be aligned on the current platform.

refsect2.title: G_CONST_RETURN
refsect2.para: If G_DISABLE_CONST_RETURNS is defined, this macro expands to nothing. By default, the macro expands to const. The macro should be used in place of const for functions that return a value that should not be modified. The purpose of this macro is to allow us to turn on const for returned constant strings by default, while allowing programmers who find that annoying to turn it off. This macro should only be used for return values and for out parameters, it doesn't make sense for in parameters.
